awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Using Mobile Sensors for Traffic Knowledge Extraction and Dynamic Network Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of the Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to develop the foundations for a new area of transportation science that takes advantage of, and addresses the challenges of using mobile traffic sensors for traffic knowledge extraction and dynamic system management. This research will study the fundamental questions of how to use widely-deployed mobile sensors for (i) estimating/predicting traffic states on arterial networks; (ii) discovering new traffic knowledge and behaviors under normal and post-disaster situations; and (iii) developing path-based dynamic network management strategies utilizing the knowledge obtained from mobile sensors. This research will develop a mobile-data-based modeling framework that will enrich current fixed-location-sensor-based modeling techniques. It will also develop theories, models, and algorithms for path-based dynamic network management strategies, with explicit consideration of multiple equilibria and real time information from mobile sensors, which will bridge various fields such as optimization, network modeling, and control theory.

This research project is expected to transform current traffic data collection and modeling from a fixed-location-sensor-based to a mobile-sensor-based paradigm and will help policy makers and industry make informed decisions on how mobile data can be best used for knowledge extraction and traffic system management. This project will develop new educational tools by integrating project-based learning in the civil engineering curriculum and will develop short courses and research seminars that will foster the communication among academia, government agencies, and industry. This work will conduct outreach activities by disseminating research and education outcomes to a wide audience that includes students in universities and K-12 schools, and in particular students in minority universities. This project will also use an external advisory panel with members from multidisciplinary backgrounds so that the research can address a broad set of questions and apply the results to other fields beyond transportation.

por.por_cntn:
With the advances and increasing deployment of emerging technologies and systems in transportation such as connected/automated vehicles and new mobility options, mobile sensors (those that move with the flow they are monitoring) are becoming ubiquitous in transportation and many other science and engineering fields. This CAREER research aimed to understand the fundamental features of mobile sensing data and developed methodologies to take the advantages and address the challenges of using mobile sensors for innovative traffic knowledge extraction and dynamic system management. This resulted in new methods and mathematical paradigms in transportation science, which have the potential to transform the way how mobile data are applied in transportation and other fields.

The research benefited many audiences, including undergraduate and graduate students, and transportation researchers and practitioners. Graduate and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, participated in the research. Results from this research were used to enhance undergraduate and graduate level courses. The PI worked closely with transportation agencies and the industry to make his best effort to convey research findings to transportation decision makers, engineers, the industry, and the academic communities.

Major findings of the research are summarized as follows:

  • Knowledge extraction: i) mobile data can be used for effective performance evaluation of transportations systems such as queue lengths of signalized intersections, vehicle emissions, freight deliveries, among others; ii) mobile-data-based modeling methods need to integrate both transportation/traffic theories and data analytics methods; iii) Stochastic modeling of traffic flow using mobile sensing data can produce more accurate and reliable results.
  • Dynamic transportation networks: i) double queue models can properly balance computational efforts and capturing traffic flow realm, and are thus more suitable for network models; ii) continuous-time dynamic network models are crucial on how to discretize/construct discrete-time models, to understand the behavior of discrete models, and to develop efficient solution methods; iii) with emerging technologies and systems, dynamic system optimum (DSO) models and principles will play increasingly important role in modeling / managing future multi-modal dynamic transportation networks; iv) dynamic network models can be used for many emerging applications in transportation such as emission pricing, evacuation, multimodal systems especially with emerging shared mobility modes.

Major outcomes of the research are summarized as follows:

  • Research activities and results: this research produced twenty-one (21) journal papers (see the detailed list below), one (1) book chapter, 8 conference proceeding papers, and a number of conference presentations.
  • Teaching activities: integrated research results to multiple courses the PI have taught in the last seven years, including: Traffic Engineering, Traffic Control and Simulation, Transportation Network Analysis, and Traffic Flow Theory on Dynamic Transportation Networks.
  • Student advising: Five (5) Ph.D. students were (partially) supported by this research.  Three (3) of them graduated in the summer of 2013, 2014, and 2016 respectively. Two (2) of them are ongoing, and plan to graduate in the fall of 2018 and the summer of 2019.
  • Undergraduate research: More than ten (10) undergraduate students worked on this research through the REU fund of this project. Three (3) of them are minority or underrepresented students. They were trained for traffic data collection, analysis, modeling, and presentation of research results.
  • Outreach: During the course of the project, the team conducted: (i) sixteen (16) invited talks and many conference presentations; (ii)  multiple meetings with traffic/ transportation practitioners on topics of mobile sensing and transportation network modeling and simulation, including New York State Department of Transportation, New York City Department of Transportation, and New York State Association of Transportation Engineers, Washington State Department of Transportation, Puget Sound Regional Council, Federal Highway Administrations, among others; (iii) dissemination of research results to the industry (e.g., Inrix, TrafficCast, Didi Chuxing, RSG) by sharing research results (papers), via face-to-facing meetings, phone calls and emails, and collaborations on research proposals.
